prompt.p: A 55-year-old man with generalized weakness in his limbs complains of difficulty swallowing. He has lost 12Â lb in weight over the last 8 months. There is no previous medical history. On examination there is muscle wasting proximally, weakness and fasciculation. Haematological investigation is normal.
What is the cause of his proximal myopathy?

modalFeedback.p: Option E (Motor neuron disease) is Correct. He has both upper and lower motor neuron signs. There is no sensory deficit. Difficulty in swallowing implies brainstem nuclei involvement.
Option A (Alcoholic myopathy) is Incorrect. There are no features of this disease.
Option B (Cushing's disease) is Incorrect. There are no features of this disease.
Option C (Diabetes mellitus) is Incorrect. There are no features of this disease.
Option D (Hyperthyroidism) is Incorrect. There are no features of this disease.
